summary: Background Acute respiratory tract infections (ARI) are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among young children and adults in developing countries, especially in africa. the majority of ARI's coronaviruses are associated with upper respiratory tract infections in developing countries. HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E belong to the alphacoronaviruses, while HCoV-OC43, HCoV-HKU1 and the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) belong to the betacoronaviruses. despite the detection of MERS-CoV-related sequences in bats worldwide, the evolutionary source of this novel HCoV remains unclear. study aims to provide information on the association of HCoVs with upper respiratory tract infections in remote rural areas of Ghana. the study was approved by the committee for human research, publications and ethics of KATH and School of Medical Sciences, KNUST, Kumasi, Ashanti region, Ghana (Ethical clearance reference: CHRPE 49/09). the study was performed in three rural areas of Ghana from September 2011 to September 2012. the Techiman municipality is among the 22 administrative districts in the region. subjects were selected as controls if they did not present with any symptom of upper respiratory illness for at least 8 days prior to recruitment. subjects were excluded if they were less than 10 years old, had a history of epistaxis or refused clinical samples to be collected. nasopharyngeal swabs were taken from 90% of all study subjects. the swabs were stored in 1.5 ml RNAlater (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) they were frozen at 20°C until testing. HCoV-229E and HCoV-OC43 multiplex RT-PCR testing was similarly performed except that 400 nM of each forward and reverse primers were used. the amplification procedure comprised reverse transcription at 55°C for 20 min followed by initial denaturation at 94°C for 3 min and 45 cycles of 94°C for 15 s and 58°C for 30 s. HCoVs were identified in 88 (12.8%) individuals in the low social contact group and 58 (11.1%) in the high social contact group. there was no significant difference (p = 0.42) in the proportion of the overall HCoVs detected in the two groups. HCoVs contribute significantly to the burden of upper respiratory tract infections. most developed countries have investigated the molecular and epidemiological profile of these viruses. the few published data were mostly from hospitalised subjects under five years. this scenario cannot be ruled out, especially because HCoV-NL63 has generally been associated with mild respiratory infection. lower levels of virus replication in controls as opposed to cases are also suggested by diverging levels of virus concentration particularly for HCoV-NL63. our study recorded high detection rates of HCoVs in the harmattan and the wet seasons compared to the other seasons. possible explanations for this include seasonal variations in host immune status to infection [47] and changes in humidity which increase viral survival in the environment. viruses are frequently detected in healthy control subjects. the use of pure virological diagnostic data is a caveat.
